page.title: 08SHEEP FARMING
page.content: The farms vary in size from approximately forty to three hundred acres, all have rough grazing or fell 'hefts' of varying sizes on which Swaledale sheep are bred _ these being usually the biggest single source of income. Enough pure Swaledales are bred to provide replacements and keep the herd numbers steady, the remaining Swale ewes are put to the Blue Faced Leicester tup to produce the Mule sheep. These Mules are very much in demand for breeding as they combine the hardiness and good mothering ability of the Swaledale with the prolific and milking abilities of the Leicester. The Mule gimmer lambs are sold at the autumn sales; many find their way to the southern counties for breeding early maturing lambs.
